Comment: Trump was raised by his father to believe that the world is made up of winners and losers, and to not be a loser.  https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/trump-the-bully-how-childhood-military-school-shaped-the-future-president/  Trump's philosophy about life in general and foreign policy in particular is informed by his positive attitudes toward bullying.    Might makes right.  Trump's idea of a Ukraine peace agreement is Ukraine's capitulation.   Putin is a winner.  Therefore, he deserves to win.  Zelensky is a loser.  Therefore, he should kiss the ring and surrender.  We saw this when Zelensky met with Trump and Vance.  Trump was utterly shocked that Zelensky wouldn't take a beating and thank him for it.    Under the same circumstances, Trump would have surrendered in a heartbeat.  Trump starts yelling at Zelensky as this is slipping away right in front of him.  Why isn't Zelensky taking an offer that he can't refuse?  There are two things that could change Trump's position: If he believes that Ukraine is winning, or if he comes to believe that Putin is not his friend, after all.  Policy makers should manage Trump accordingly.

Comment: How? Ukraine neither has the manpower nor equipment to decisively defeat Russia. They can keep this defence up for years, sure, but without an injection of both weapons systems and manpower they can't mount the offensives they need.¬†   The path to victory in Ukraine involves the collapse of the Russian economy or the exhaustion for war of its population. Neither of those things seem to be happening, unfortunately.¬†   The Russian population being fed into the grinder are not the sons of those who have the power to force Putin to stop, and the Russian economy has been in shambles for decades, this is no different.   That leaves the only option of the west putting boots on the ground, and I think they should, but no politician anywhere in the world has the balls to risk a potential nuclear exchange.
